A cervical cap is a small silicone cup a woman puts into her vagina before sex. It prevents pregnancy by covering the cervix so the man’s sperm can't get into the woman’s womb.

A cervical cap only provides protection when it is inside you and it works best when you also use spermicide. A cervical cap lasts for many years.

  • How to use

    With clean hands, put about a ¼ teaspoon of spermicide inside the cap and also on the top side of the cap, beneath the removal strap. With the strap side down, squeeze the rim of the cap together and gently insert the cap inside you until it covers the cervix.

    Put the cervical cap in before sex, even hours before if you want. To be protected from pregnancy, leave it in for at least 6 hours after sex, but no more than 48 hours. Remove it by pushing gently on the dome to break the suction, then crooking a finger under the removal strap to pull it out. Clean with mild soap and water and let dry in the air.

  • Many women think a cervical cap is great because…
    • It can be put in hours before having sex.
    • They don’t want to use hormones.
    • It uses less spermicide than a diaphragm.
    • Cervical caps don’t affect your period.
    But some women don’t like the cervical cap because:
    • You must remember to have it with you.
    • It must be used correctly every time you have sex.
    • They don’t want to put anything into their vagina.
    • It can be difficult to insert correctly.
    • It should be used with spermicide too.
    • Chemicals in spermicide can irritate the vagina.
    • Its use can cause urinary tract infections.
  • Who shouldn’t use it

    Women who are allergic to silicone or the chemicals in spermicides shouldn't use a cervical cap. Women with HIV should not use spermicides.
